'''Manuel "Manolo" Díaz Elizalde Sr.'''<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://philippines.mom-rsf.org/en/owners/individual-owners/detail/owner/owner/show/the-elizalde-family/ |title=The Elizalde Family |website=philippines.mom-rsf.org |language=en |access-date=2018-05-29}}</ref><ref name="Borja2005">{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com.ph/books?id=xXpiujH2uOwC&pg=PA129&lpg=PA129&dq=manolo+elizalde&source=bl&ots=vefy2vQdUs&sig=D_4hXQUKe-BW6QaUM1qQQj5OVy0&hl=fil&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj2meiy16rbAhVFNrwKHeWCDJ0Q6AEIVTAL#v=onepage&q=manolo%2520elizalde&f=false |title=Basques in the Philippines |last=Borja |first=Marciano R. De |date=2005 |publisher=University of Nevada Press |isbn=9780874175905 |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite magazine |title=The Most Influential and Enduring Families of the Philippines |url=https://www.townandcountry.ph/people/heritage/who-are-the-most-generous-enduring-families-of-the-philippines-a1590-20161104-lfrm2 |magazine=Townandcountry.ph}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.philstar.com/sports/2005/03/16/270529/pba-hall-fame |title=PBA Hall of Fame |work=The Philippine Star |access-date=2018-05-29}}</ref> was a prominent Spanish Filipino businessman.
==Biography== Elizalde was born in [[Manila]] to José Joaquín Elizalde and Carmen Díaz Moreau. He was a brother of diplomat [[Joaquín Miguel Elizalde|Joaquin]] ("Mike"), Juan Miguel, Angel, [[Fred Elizalde|Federico]] ("Fred") and Carmenchu Elizalde.
During the 1920s, he was nicknamed "Lizz" Elizalde, playing the [[clarinet]] and the [[saxophone]] alongside his brother Fred.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/manuel-lizz-elizalde-mn0001484139|title=Manuel "Lizz" Elizalde biography|first=Eugene|last=Chadbourne|work=AllMusic|date=|access-date=31 May 2018}}</ref>
He was married to Mary Cadwallader and among the couple's children was [[Manuel Elizalde|Manuel "Manda" Elizalde Jr.]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1970/08/13/archives/tribesmens-mentor.html|title=Tribesman's Mentor|first=|last=|work=The New York Times|date=13 August 1970|access-date=31 May 2018}}</ref>
==Business== In 1936, he and his brothers established Elizalde & Company, Inc. after acquiring the major businesses of [[Ynchausti y Compañía]], among them Ynchausti Shipping, [[Tanduay]], YCO Paints and Floor Wax, Rizal Cement, and the Central Azucarera de La Carlota and Central Azucarera de Pilar (now Capiz Sugar Central) sugar refineries.<ref>{{cite book|last=de Borja|first=Marciano R|title=Basques in the Philippines|year=2005|publisher=University of Nevada Press|location=Nevada|isbn=0-87417-590-9|pages=128–131}}</ref> After [[World War II]], Elizalde became president of the company after his brother Mike decided to step down from the position in order to focus on his diplomatic career.
In 1946, Elizalde and his brothers established [[Manila Broadcasting Company]] to acquire the radio stations [[DZRH|KZRH]] and [[DYRC|KYRC]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.congress.gov.ph/legisdocs/basic_17/HB04136.pdf|title=H.B. 4136|first=|last=House of Representatives, Republic of the Philippines|date=|access-date=4 June 2018}}</ref>
==Sports== From the 1920s to the 1930s, Elizalde was an avid [[polo]] player together with his brothers [[Joaquin Miguel Elizalde|Mike]], Juan Miguel and Angel. In January 1937, the Elizalde brothers inaugurated the Los Tamaraos Polo Club in [[Parañaque]] after resigning their memberships in the Manila Polo Club in protest to the rejection of the membership application of Manuel Nieto, [[aide-de-camp]] of Philippine President [[Manuel L. Quezon]]. The Elizalde brothers proposed and seconded Nieto's membership application.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://philippinediaryproject.wordpress.com/1936/03/24/march-24-1936/|title=Diary of Francis Burton Harrison, March 24, 1935|first=F.B.|last=Harrison|work=The Philippine Diary Project|date=|access-date=31 May 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.manilatimes.net/polo-history-in-the-philippines/109284/|title=Polo history in the Philippines|first=|last=|work=The Manila Times|date=5 July 2014|access-date=31 May 2018}}</ref>
As a sports patron, he founded the [[YCO Painters|YCO]] and the original [[Tanduay Rhum Masters|Tanduay]] basketball teams.
== References == {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Elizalde, Manolo}} [[Category:Filipino people of Spanish descent]] [[Category:Filipino people of Basque descent]] [[Category:People from Manila]] [[Category:Filipino businesspeople]] [[Category:1985 deaths]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox writer <!-- for more information see [[:Template:Infobox writer/doc]] --> | name = Mary Lee Ware | image = Mary Lee Ware.jpg | caption = Mary Lee Ware by farm gate | birth_date = {{Birth date|1858|01|7}} | birth_place = | death_date = {{Death date and age|1937|1|09|1858|01|7}} | death_place = 41 Brimmer Street, [[Boston, Massachusetts]] | resting_place = [[Mount Auburn Cemetery]] | occupation = Farmer, philanthropist | nationality = American | alma_mater = [[Radcliffe College]] | spouse = | children = | relatives = Elizabeth Cabot Lee (Mother), Charles Eliot Ware (Father), [[Francis Parkman]] (First Cousin)<ref>Massachusetts Historical Society - https://www.masshist.org/blog/1469</ref> | influences = | influenced = | awards = | signature = Mary Lee Ware's Signature.jpg }}
'''Mary Lee Ware''', (Jan. 7, 1858 – Jan. 9, 1937)<ref>{{cite web|title=Mary Lee Ware|url=http://records.ancestry.com/mary_lee_ware_records.ashx?pid=8757808|website=Ancestry.com|publisher=Ancestry|accessdate=14 January 2016}}</ref>{{primary source inline|date=March 2017}}<ref>Hale, Emily. Mary Lee Ware, Jan. 7, 1858- Jan. 9, 1937. N.p, 1937. Print.</ref> daughter of [[Elizabeth Cabot (Lee) Ware]] and [[Charles Eliot Ware]], was born to a wealthy Bostonian family and, with her mother, was the principal sponsor of the [[Harvard Museum of Natural History]]'s famous [[Glass Flowers]] (formally ''The Ware Collection of Blaschka Glass Models of Plants'').<ref>{{cite web|title=The Glass Flowers|url=http://hmnh.harvard.edu/glass-flowers|website=Harvard Museum of Natural History|publisher=The President and Fellows of Harvard College|accessdate=14 January 2016}}</ref> She was an avid student of botany, particularly of the work of [[George Lincoln Goodale]]; a close friend and sponsor of [[Leopold and Rudolf Blaschka]], creators of the Glass Flowers; and a leading philanthropist and farmer of [[West Rindge, New Hampshire]] and [[Boston, Massachusetts]].
==Early life== Born into a respected family in the New Hampshire town of [[Rindge, New Hampshire|Rindge]], specifically to [[naturalist]] and [[Harvard Medical School]] professor Dr. Charles Eliot Ware ("a leading physician in Boston"<ref name="mfa.org">{{Cite news|url=http://www.mfa.org/collections/object/the-british-fleet-forming-a-line-off-algiers-32602|title=The British Fleet Forming a Line off Algiers|date=2018-03-16|work=Museum of Fine Arts, Boston|access-date=2018-04-24|language=en}}</ref>) and his wife Elizabeth in 1858, Mary Lee Ware was an avid nature-lover and lived according to the precept "It is more blessed to give than to receive."<ref name=hale>Hale, Emily. Mary Lee Ware. Boston, 1937. Print.</ref> Taken to Italy as a young girl, Mary was dazzled by the many sights (such as Rome and Florence) there, which served to enhance her love of beautiful things. Beauty that ranged from the picturesque landscape to the language which she quickly excelled, to the art for which the country is famous. This is no surprise given that her father, Dr. Charles Ware (Harvard class of 1834<ref name="Charles Eliot Ware">{{Cite book|url=https://archive.org/details/jstor-20021531|title=Charles Eliot Ware|date=1887-05-01|publisher=Proceedings of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences|others=JSTOR}}</ref>), while not a botanist himself raised his daughter to love botany with a passion. A love which was fostered by the family farm in Rindge New Hampshire, a place which stood out happily among her childhood memories.<ref name=hale /> Mary eventually (exactly when is unclear given source ambiguity) settled with her parents and possibly brother, Charles Jr. (reports/sources vary regarding his existence, with the bare majority suggesting it) in Boston, 41 Brimmer Street (Back Bay), around 1870; at that time, Mary was 13 years old. She was also, at some point, a student of [[Radcliffe College]] and learned under Dr. Goodale<ref name=rossi>Rossi-Wilcox, Susan M., and David Whitehouse. Drawing upon Nature: Studies for the Blaschkas' Glass Models. Corning, NY: Corning Museum of Glass, 2007. Print.</ref><ref name=daston>Daston, Lorraine. Things That Talk: Object Lessons from Art and Science. New York: Zone, 2004. Print.</ref> - who would become the first director of the Harvard Botanical Museum. In fact, "Mary Ware, an especially fascinating character, became in many respects a professional naturalist," a role which she was later able to utilize by being the patron sponsor of the Glass Flowers, her purpose being to advance the education of women.<ref>Making Harvard’s Glass Flowers: the interface of Botany Gender and Artistic Virtuosity in America. A thesis presented by Rupal Christine Pinto, Harvard University Cambridge MA, March 2002 quoting Susan Rossi Wilcox et al “Conservation Survey” Appendix</ref>
==The Glass Flowers== [[File:PSM V39 D594 George Lincoln Goodale.jpg|thumb|Professor George Lincoln Goodale|right|150px]] The "ever-loyal and ever-generous"<ref name=daston /> Mary Lee Ware and her mother were drawn into the Glass Flowers enterprise in 1886 when her former teacher, Professor George Goodale, approached them with his idea to populate the new Botanical Museum (of which he was the first director) with Blaschka glass specimens.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.psu.edu/story/140881/1999/09/01/research/flowers-out-glass|title=Flowers Out of Glass {{!}} Penn State University|access-date=2018-04-24|language=en}}</ref> Being independently wealthy and (already) liberal benefactors of Harvard's botany department,<ref>Flowers that never fade / Franklin Baldwin Wiley. Boston Bradlee Whidden, Publisher 1897</ref> Mary convinced her mother to agree to underwrite the 200 [[Mark (currency)|mark]] consignment,<ref>{{cite book|title=Memoirs of the National Academy of Sciences Vol XXI|date=1927|publisher=United States Government Printing Office|location=Washington, D.C.|url=http://www.nasonline.org/publications/biographical-memoirs/memoir-pdfs/goodale-george.pdf|accessdate=14 January 2016}}</ref><ref name="Goodyear, Anne Collins 2013">Goodyear, Anne Collins, and Weitekamp, Margaret A. Analyzing Art and Aesthetics. Artefacts: Studies in the History of Science and Technology ; v. 9. 2013.</ref> but this was done anonymously at first (and would remain so until 1888).<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.warefamilies.org/2012/03/mrs-elizabeth-c-ware/|title=Mrs. Elizabeth C. Ware {{!}} Ware|website=www.warefamilies.org|language=en-US|access-date=2018-04-24}}</ref> The uncannily lifelike models arrived in the spring of 1887 and enchanted the Wares. Then, that same year, Dr. Charles Ware died,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi/page/gr/%3Chttp://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=148047539|title=Dr Charles Elliott [sic] Ware (1814-1887) - Find A Grave...|website=www.findagrave.com|access-date=2018-04-24}}</ref> thus filling the two women with the desire to provide Harvard with a donation in his memory.<ref name="Goodyear, Anne Collins 2013"/> Hence, when the official contract was signed between the Mary and her mother, Leopold and Rudolf, and Harvard, the agreement was that the collection would be a memorial to the now deceased Doctor: "The first Blaschka glass flowers are formally presented to the Botanical Museum as a memorial to Dr. Charles Eliot Ware, Class of 1834, by his widow Elizabeth C. Ware and daughter Mary L. Ware."<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{cite web|title=This month in Harvard history|url=http://news.harvard.edu/gazette/2005/04.07/02-history.html|website=Harvard University Gazette|publisher=The President and Fellows of Harvard College|accessdate=14 January 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Reports of the President and the Treasurer of Harvard College|date=1920–1921|publisher=Harvard University|page=5717|url=http://pds.lib.harvard.edu/pds/view/2574586?n=5717|accessdate=14 January 2016}}</ref> Today, there is a large bronze plaque in the exhibit's center formally dedicating it to the nature-loving Doctor, father, and husband. The initial contract signed dictated that the Blaschkas need only work half-time on the models, thus allowing them to continue their work making [[Glass sea creatures|glass marine invertebrates]]. However, in 1890, they and Goodale - acting on behalf of the Wares - signed an updated version that allowed Leopold and Rudolf to work on them (the Glass Flowers) full-time;<ref name=schultes>Schultes, Richard Evans., William A. Davis, and Hillel Burger. The Glass Flowers at Harvard. New York: Dutton, 1982. Print.</ref><ref name=ware>{{cite web|title=The Archives of Rudolph and Leopold Blaschka and the Ware Collection of Blaschka Glass Models of Plants|url=http://botlib.huh.harvard.edu/libraries/glass.htm|website=Harvard University Herbaria|publisher=The President and Fellows of Harvard College|accessdate=14 January 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cmog.org/article/blaschkas-glass-botanical-models-1886-1936|title=All About Glass {{!}} Corning Museum of Glass|website=www.cmog.org|language=en|access-date=2018-04-24}}</ref> some sources detail the agreement as a shift from a 3-year contract to a 10-year one, agreed to once Goodale convinced Mary and her mother of the wisdom in doing so.<ref name=rossi /> It is also noted by Prof. Goodale in the ''Annual reports of the President and Treasurer of Harvard College 1890-1891'' that the updated contract was partly due to the Blaschkas insisting that it was impossible to craft the botanical models for half the year and the marine ones the other half; "they said that they must give up either one or the other." Furthermore, the report notes that the activity of the Blaschka "has been greatly increased by their exclusive devotion to a single a single line of work."<ref>Annual reports of the President and Treasurer of Harvard College 1890-1891, pp. 160-163 - https://iiif.lib.harvard.edu/manifests/view/drs:427018526$1i</ref> Later, in 1889, Leopold made and gifted a bouquet of glass flowers to the Wares which, at some later date, was given to Harvard and is now part of the Glass Flowers exhibit.<ref name=harvard>Harvard University Herbaria and Botany Libraries</ref><ref>Rossi-Wilcox, Susan M. "A Brief History of Harvard's Glass Flowers Collection and Its Development." Journal of Glass Studies (2015): 197-211.</ref>
===Specific role=== [[File:Ware Dedication plaque.jpg|thumb|left|The plaque in the Harvard Museum of Natural History's Glass Flowers exhibit, formally dedicating it to Dr. Charles Eliot Ware.]] [[File:Glass Flowers gift-bouquet.jpg|thumb|right|Glass Flowers gift-bouquet]] Early in the making of the Glass Flowers, Mary Lee Ware engaged in correspondence with Professor Goodale regarding the making of the collection, one of which contained a remark of Leopold's regarding the false rumor that secret methods were used in the making of the Glass Flowers: ''"Many people think that we have some secret apparatus by which we can squeeze glass suddenly into these forms, but it is not so. We have tact. My son Rudolf has more than I have, because he is my son, and tact increases in every generation. The only way to become a glass modeler of skill, I have often said to people, is to get a good great-grandfather who loved glass."'' Miss Ware is also known to have visited the Blaschka home/studio three times, the first in 1899 along with Prof. Goodale, Mrs Goodale and their son Francis. By this time Mary was the sole benefactress of the Blaschkas, as her mother, Elizabeth C. Ware, had died the previous year (1898<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi/page/gr/%3Chttp://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=148054012|title=Elizabeth Cabot Lee Ware (1819-1898) - Find A...|website=www.findagrave.com|access-date=2018-04-24}}</ref>). During the course of these visits she became very great friends with Rudolf and his wife Frieda, and, on one occasion, Rudolf wrote to Mary L. Ware regarding his vision of how the Flowers should be displayed: ''"I think pure white sheets will do best as bestow good light to the whole room. The models will look best either on pure white or a deep velvet-black."''<ref>Goodyear, Anne Collins, and Weitekamp, Margaret A. Analyzing Art and Aesthetics. Artefacts: Studies in the History of Science and Technology; v. 9. 2013.</ref> A preference Harvard evidently agreed with as, to this day, the botanical model are wired down to pure white boards within the original (albeit [http://www.secondlife.net/ refurbished]) cases. Regardless, Mary's second visit was around 1908 and the third on October 3, 1928. This second visit, made after Leopold's death, was related via a letter from Miss Ware to the second director of the Botanical Museum, Professor [[Oakes Ames (botanist)|Oakes Ames]].<ref name=schultes /> This letter appears to confirm the previous statement of Leopold's regarding his son; Miss Ware writes, ''"One change in the character of his work and, consequently in the time necessary to accomplish results since I was last here, is very noteworthy. At that time...he bought most of his glass and was just beginning to make some, and his finish was in paint. Now he himself makes a large part of the glass and all the enamels, which he powders to use as paint."''<ref name=daston /> This missive to Professor Ames was published in January 9, 1961 by the [[Harvard University Herbaria]] - Botanical Museum Leaflets, Harvard University Vol. 19, No. 6 - under the title "How Were The Glass Flowers Made?"<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ware|first=Mary Lee|last2=S.|first2=R. E.|date=1961|title=HOW WERE THE GLASS FLOWERS MADE?|jstor=41762212|journal=Botanical Museum Leaflets, Harvard University|volume=19|issue=6|pages=125–136}}</ref> In addition to funding and visiting, Mary took a fairly active role in the project's progress, going so far as to personally unpack each model<ref name=ware /> and making arrangements for Rudolph's fieldwork in the U.S. and Jamaica<ref name=ware /> – the purpose of such trips being to gather and study various plant specimens before returning to the old style Bohemian lamp-working table at which he (and Leopold) worked.
It is also known that, in 1898, Mary Lee Ware was made a member of the Committee of Overseers on the Botanic Garden and the Botanic Museum - an addition that was met with pleasure by its members, including Professor Goodale. Indeed, Miss Ware's "generous gifts of money and time for the advancement of the Department...[were] already known from the previous [Harvard] Annual Reports.<ref>{{cite book|title=Reports of the President and the Treasurer of Harvard College|date=1898–1899|publisher=Harvard University|page=4622|url=http://pds.lib.harvard.edu/pds/viewtext/2574409?n=4622&s=4&printThumbnails=no|accessdate=14 January 2016}}</ref>
Upon her death in 1937, Miss Ware left a will with assets worth one million dollars, $600,000 of which she bequeathed on charity and education. Of this vast sum, a full half of it (the largest single bequest in her will) was given to Harvard for completion and the upkeep of the Glass Flowers (as well as support Rudolf and Frieda).<ref name=harvard /><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/45694008/|title=Fitchburg Sentinel from Fitchburg, Massachusetts on January 15, 1937 · Page 1|work=Newspapers.com|access-date=2018-04-24|language=en}}</ref>
==The Ware Farm and agricultural work== [[File:Ware farm.jpg|thumb|right|upright=1.5|The Ware family farm in Rindge NH]] Although her mother remained in Boston, Mary Lee Ware clearly considered herself a New Hampshirite and apparently maintained the West Rindge family farm of her childhood. However, she is almost always called Miss Mary Lee Ware of Boston; very rarely is Rindge, NH mentioned. Reportedly (per the majority of sources) she was a seasonal resident of both Massachusetts and New Hampshire, spending the summers at the Ware Farm in Rindge while wintering in Boston with her mother.<ref name=harvard /> The Ware Farm was sold to Mary's father, Dr. Ware, by a Joseph Davis and Dorestos Armory for $3000 in 1868 – the place having 450 total acres, 21.5 dedicated to pasture land with another 56.5 for cultivation.<ref name=harvard /> Housing from two to forty people (mostly hired hands), the place was spared from a massive tornado that, on September 13, 1928, hit West Rindge. Enduring for twenty minutes, the disaster leveled the land and resulted in a $100,000 loss for the town. Thankfully, "the beautiful Mary Lee Ware estate proper was not damaged," yet the estate workers' homes suffered via falling trees. Her estate manager, William S. Cleaves, fled his truck - to the relative safety of his home - in the nick of time, just before a falling tree crushed it.<ref>{{cite web|last1=gendisasters|title=West Rindge, NH Tornado, Sept 1928|url=http://www3.gendisasters.com/new-hampshire/15064/west-rindge-nh-tornado-sept-1928|website=GenDisasters.com|accessdate=15 January 2016}}</ref> Years earlier, in 1887<ref>{{cite journal |title= Charles Eliot Ware |journal= Proceedings of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences |volume= 23 |issue= 2 |pages= 346–347 |date= May 1888 |jstor= 20021531}}</ref><ref name="Charles Eliot Ware"/> and 1898 respectively, the farm saw the death of both Miss Ware's parents, Dr. Charles Eliot and Elizabeth C. Ware, making Mary the sole heiress of the estate. Later, in 1931, the Ware farm was the location of her cousin Cordelia E. Ware's wedding (specifically, Cordelia was Mary L. Ware's first cousin once removed on her father's side - the child of his first cousin John Ware).<ref name=harvard />
Under Mary Lee Ware's strict but kind jurisdiction the farm blossomed, so to speak, with Miss Ware expanding it to a scale beyond that of what her parents enjoyed. Between 1898 (the year of her mother's death) and 1936 (a year before she died), she wired the entire farm for electricity, built gardens, all-season greenhouses, equipment barns, and a dairy and ice-house, purchased the neighboring Carr Farm and acreage (later the Ruth Morris Farm) which extends Ware Farm to the eastern shore of Pool Pond (approx. 500 acres), established a water system, and maintained a large-scale chicken operation on the acquired Carr Farm.<ref name="hoofandclaw.org">{{cite web |url=http://www.hoofandclaw.org/ware/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-03-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160311164611/http://www.hoofandclaw.org/ware/ |archivedate=2016-03-11 |df= }}</ref> The Farm was known to be "an outstanding showplace with Jersey cows, poultry, a piggery, sheep, and Irish Settlers, all purebred...in 1911, her three foundation cows and a bull were imported from the Isle of Jersey."<ref>The Artist in Monadnock Farmyards by Ann Sawyer (9780557721603; Lulu.com), p. 30</ref> Her affection for the family and its many non-family residents is illustrated by the fact that, upon her death, Mary's will designated funds to keep the farm and her "farm family" together for one full year.<ref name="hoofandclaw.org"/>
===Legacy=== It is known that, by at least 1913, Miss Ware was a member of the [[New Hampshire Horticultural Society]].<ref>Annual Report, Vols. 5-8, by New Hampshire Horticultural Society, 1913, page 107</ref> The Grange Hall in Rindge was also named after her — the Mary L. Ware Grange Hall — doubtless in tribute to her many agricultural contributions; and, in addition, a Mary L. Ware Park was established in West Rindge.<ref name="hoofandclaw.org"/><ref>Annual report of the Town of Rindge New Hampshire 1996</ref> Sadly, in 1957, the Hall was bought and converted into the Ed’s Country Auction House by Mr. Edward Gilman "Ed" Stevens.<ref name="hoofandclaw.org"/><ref>{{cite news|title=Edward Gilman "Ed" Stevens|url=http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/unionleader/obituary.aspx?n=edward-gilman-stevens-ed&pid=150782875|accessdate=15 January 2016|work=New Hampshire Union Leader|date=4 May 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Edward G. Stevens|url=http://www.sentinelsource.com/news/obituaries/edward-g-stevens/article_1a5b9a26-766c-11e0-ad02-001cc4c03286.html|website=SentinelSource.com|publisher=SentinelSource.com|accessdate=15 January 2016|date=4 May 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=[The Amvet auxiliary met this week in the Mary L. Ware Grange hall]|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/45699772/|accessdate=15 January 2016|work=Fitchburg Sentinel|date=28 March 1947|page=26}}</ref> Furthermore, in regards to Miss Ware's agrarian impact, the [[New Hampshire Farm Bureau]]'s highest award was once the ''Mary Lee Ware Trophy''.<ref>{{cite news|title=Stacey Ward Cole|url=http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/unionleader/obituary.aspx?pid=173350846|accessdate=15 January 2016|work=New Hampshire Union Leader|date=3 December 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Stacey W. Cole|url=|website=SentinelSource.com|publisher=SentinelSource.com|date=3 December 2014}}</ref> Regarding her will, Mary left $25000 to her Boston and West Rindge employees.<ref name=harvard /> As to the Ware Farm itself, it was given to "certain relatives and their children"<ref name=harvard /> but eventually passed out of the family's hands.
However, the Ware Farm remains in active use today. "In 2002 Steve and Beverly Lindell purchased the property, resurrected the Ware Farm name, and have since tended and cherished the property in a manner complimentary to its heritage: original buildings are lovingly preserved; the flower gardens are spellbinding and constantly abuzz with pollinators; horses roam and graze the pastures; it's forest is managed in conservation through the Monadnock Conservancy. The farm presently consists of 230 acres, the majority on the east side of Woodbound Road, matching closely the original Ware Farm footprint."<ref name="hoofandclaw.org"/> Today the farm is the home-base of [http://www.hoofandclaw.org/#intro ''HOOF&CLAW''] - a training and consultation center for dog handling and horsemanship - as well as the home of Blaine Capone, HOOF&CLAW's founder.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.hoofandclaw.org/about/#bio|title=MISSION|website=BESOTORO|language=en-US|access-date=2018-04-24}}</ref> Mr. Capone, in turn, continues to honor the legacy and philanthropic spirit of Miss Ware, insofar as her deep love of nature went, working with HOOF&CLAW to preserve the environment and inspire solutions to environmental issues.
==Community involvement== As a Philanthropist of many interests, Mary Lee Ware contributed in other many and varied ways to the States of Massachusetts and New Hampshire. However, though "well known locally in NH and Boston for charitable works, she often kept her donations anonymous from the public."<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://eraven.franklinpierce.edu/academicshowcase/2017/marulli.htm|title=Marulli: Academic Showcase|website=eraven.franklinpierce.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-04-24}}</ref>
===Massachusetts=== Aside from the Glass Flower enterprise, Mary Lee Ware supported Harvard University in other ways, donating four table cases to the Economic Room<ref>{{cite book|title=Reports of the President and the Treasurer of Harvard College|date=1929–1930|publisher=Harvard University|page=245|url=http://pds.lib.harvard.edu/pds/viewtext/2582401?n=245&s=4&printThumbnails=no|accessdate=14 January 2016}}</ref> along with various sums of money for research and preservation purposes, as is evidenced in various Harvard Treasurer's Statements. In addition, she was one of early anthropologist [[Frederic Ward Putnam]] of the [[Peabody Museum of Archaeology and Ethnology]] many wealthy donors.<ref name=":1" /> Correspondences between her and Putnam reveals that Miss Ware provided a significant amount of money for America’s first preserved archaeological site in 1886: [[Serpent Mound]] in Ohio, along with Putnam’s other later archaeological endeavors.<ref name=":1" />
Between 1928 and her death (1937), Miss Ware sent a short letter to John Templeton Coolidge regarding a set of [[spur]]s she found among her cousin Mr. Hall's books. Spurs which, she speculated, were worn by famed [[historian]] [[Francis Parkman]] during his expedition he ''[[The Oregon Trail (book)|The Oregon Trail]]''.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=https://www.masshist.org/blog/1469|title=Massachusetts Historical Society: the Beehive|website=www.masshist.org|language=en|access-date=2018-04-24}}</ref> The main body of the letter to Mr. Coolidge reads "''The spurs I found among Mr. Hall’s army outfit, labelled “F.P.[”] as you see, and we wondered if by any chance they could have been worn by Mr. Parkman on his “Oregon Trail” journey. It is of course only a guess, but certainly F.P. could only mean Mr. Parkman and Miss Lizzie might have given them to Mr. Hall as a keep-sake. If they were his, possibly your son Jack would like them. If not, you can of course do as you please with them.''" Miss Ware's cousin, this Mr. Hall, is presumed to be [[Henry Ware Hall]] seeing as he shared an uncle with Francis Parkman: "Edward Brooks Hall—the same Hall who had married Mary Lee Ware’s aunt Harriet. So Henry, Francis, and Mary were all first cousins." Mary Lee Ware sent the letter to Mr. Coolidge because he was Parkman’s son-in-law. Said letter was recently obtained by the [[Massachusetts Historical Society]].<ref name=":2" />
Mary's interest in history and cultural artifacts is further noted by the fact that the first annual meeting of the [[Society for the Preservation of New England Antiquities]] was held at her 41 Brimmer Street Boston home.<ref>The Magazine of History with Notes and Queries, Volume 13</ref>
Mary L. Ware did at least some work with the Christian Register, helping in the selection of letters in a 1917 edition.<ref>Christian Register - Volume 96 - Page 1190</ref> Furthermore, from at least 1906 to 1913 she was a member of the Women's Christian Temperance Union, as known by a pair of letters she exchanged during those respective years to [[Anne Whitney]], a reputable Massachusetts poet and sculptor.<ref>Papers of Anne Whitney, 1834-1915: a guide. MSS.4 - http://academics.wellesley.edu/lts/archives/mss.4.html - https://www.wellesley.edu/sites/default/files/assets/departments/libraryandtechnology/files/archives/mss.4.pdf</ref>
Miss Ware attended the first annual meeting of the [[Woman's National Farm & Garden Association]]'s New England Branch in Boston, and was elected to the position of "Chairman Executive Committee."<ref>Woman's National Farm and Garden Association Bulletin, Volume 6, Issue 8, page 12</ref>
Mary was a corporate member of the [[Massachusetts School for Idiotic and Feeble-Minded Youth]], along with her cousins Charles E. and Harriet P. Ware of Fitchburg and (possible relative) Mrs. Mary G. Ware of Lancaster.<ref>Annual Report of the Trustees of the Massachusetts School for Idiotic and Feeble-Minded Youth</ref><ref>Public documents of Massachusetts, Volume 8</ref>
Mary Lee Ware was an officer in the [[Massachusetts Forestry Association]]<ref>The Lumber Manufacturer and Dealer, Volume 66</ref> from at least 1906 to 1915, occupying such roles as one of many Vice-Presidents, a member of the Executive Committee along with Ways and Means<ref>Pamphlets on Forestry in Massachusetts, Volume 10</ref> as well as being the Chairman of the Membership and Publications Committee.<ref>Massachusetts Forestry Association - Woodland and Roadside, Volumes 1-4</ref><ref>Massachusetts Forestry Association - [https://books.google.com/books?id=TLMAAAAAYAAJ&pg=RA1-PA47&lpg=RA1-PA47&dq=Mary+Lee+Ware&source=bl&ots=4_CSDm6frX&sig=1Du_TIGWWKcU4AEyyaq-TajFaGE&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwit-O6P1tXQAhVm7oMKHXu-Cq84ChDoAQgsMAQ#v=onepage&q=Mary%20Lee%20Ware&f=false Woodland and Roadside: Volumes 5-8]</ref> As in so many of her roles she was, curiously and again, known as "Mary Lee Ware of Boston," though this could easily be due to her seemingly preferred Rindge residence being outside of Massachusetts.
===New Hampshire=== Similarly showing her love of the natural world, in 1901–1902 Mary Lee Ware played a pivotal role in the creation of the New Hampshire [[Rhododendron State Park]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.sentinelsource.com/community/weeklies/taking-it-one-room-at-a-time-rindge-historical-society/article_fc498610-9eb6-532b-b2c4-11c6694c3171.html|title=Taking it one room at a time Rindge Historical Society preserves 256 years of history|last=BOROZINSKI|first=AMANDA|work=SentinelSource.com|access-date=2018-04-24|language=en}}</ref> when, in 1901, subsequent owner Levi Fuller planned to "lumber off" the property and would have if not for Mary, who bought it in 1902. Giving it to the [[Appalachian Mountain Club]] (AMC) a year later, she signed the deal on the condition that the woodland "...be held as a reservation properly protected and open to the public...forever."<ref>{{cite web|title=Rhododendron State Park|url=http://www.newhampshire.com/article/99999999/NEWHAMPSHIRE0304/110419946/0/55|website=NewHampshire.com|publisher=NewHampshire.com|accessdate=15 January 2016|date=19 April 2011}}</ref><ref>Rhododendron State Park Park History - https://www.nhstateparks.org/uploads/RhododendronStatePark_History_2010.pdf</ref> The contract also barred cutting down any trees or picking any [[rhododendron]], a promise that has been broken only once due to the 1938 hurricane.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Old Patch Place|url=http://www.beqbooks.com/rhodo/patch.htm|website=Bequaert Old Books|publisher=Frank Bequaert|accessdate=15 January 2016}}</ref> The donated land is called "Old Patch Place," remodeled by the AMC as a hostel/clubhouse but has since (1946) come under the protection of the N.H. Division of Parks and Recreation — the system's only designated botanical park. The "Old Patch Place" cottage near the park entrance was listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]] in 1980.
Miss Ware was a unit chairwoman of the Women's Committee and Council of National Defense in the Granite State, working with the Federal Food Administrator of New Hampshire.<ref>The Granite Monthly: A Magazine of Literature, History and State Progress, Volume 51, p. 200-202</ref>
Also, the [[Rindge Historical Society]] Museum's collection of artifacts "began with the efforts of Mary Lee Ware...a seasonal resident of Rindge. Ms. Ware, around the turn of the twentieth century, took it upon herself to solicit donations of historical items from the town’s residents."<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.rindgehistoricalsociety.org/?page_id=59|title=The Collection|date=2015-03-23|work=Rindge Historical Society|access-date=2018-04-24|language=en-US}}</ref> This collection, today located near the center of Rindge, was once housed at the Ingalls Memorial Library (which would itself later benefit from Mary's generosity). Indeed, in the very first issue of the Rindge Community Newsletter (a volunteer effort by the Rindge Chamber of Commerce), Mary L. Ware was credited with the founding of the Rindge Museum, stating that she asked for the historical donations per "a large horse-drawn wagon and a few of her hired men."<ref>Google cache of a 2012 Newsletter from the Rindge Chamber of Commerce - http://webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache:hZ9MsbTMMHMJ:rindgechamber.org/newsletter/2012/Final%2520Newsletter.pdf+&cd=1&hl=en&ct=clnk&gl=us</ref>
==Death== [[File:The grave of Mary Lee Ware at Mt. Auburn Cemetery.jpg|thumb|The grave of Mary Lee Ware at Mt. Auburn Cemetery]] The circumstances of Mary Lee Ware's death - which took place a few months after the Glass Flowers enterprise ended - is described in a letter addressed to Professor Oakes Ames. On January 5 "the poor old lady had a heavy stroke which left her almost completely paralyzed. There seemed to be no question whatever but that she could not possibly recover and, four days later, she had another shock which, thank God, carried her peacefully off."<ref name=harvard /> Having died at her 41 Brimmer Street Boston home at the age of 79, Miss Ware was buried next to her parents at [[Mt. Auburn Cemetery]], her funeral taking place on January 12 at [[King's Chapel]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/45693823/|title=Fitchburg Sentinel from Fitchburg, Massachusetts on January 13, 1937 · Page 3|work=Newspapers.com|access-date=2018-04-24|language=en}}</ref> and officiated over by Reverends John and Palfrey Perkins with many notable personages in attendance, including Francis Goodale (Prof. Goodale's son).<ref name=harvard /> Acting as an usher at the funeral was a child named Charles E. Ware 3rd, presumably the son of her cousin Charles Eliot Ware of [[Fitchburg, Massachusetts|Fitchburg]] of whom her will designated a favorable sum.<ref name=harvard /> Indeed, another letter to Professor Ames states that a letter of condolence should be sent to Charles E. Ware of Fitchburg, furthering the appearance that the two cousins were close.<ref name=harvard /> Miss Mary L. Ware's death was, in addition, reportedly taken hard by Rudolf Blaschka, whose own health was beginning to fail (as detailed in another letter to Professor Ames by Mr. Louis C. Bierweiler, former assistant to Professor [[Louis Agassiz]]).<ref name=harvard /><ref>Reports of the President and the Treasurer of Harvard College</ref> In addition, a later letter from a solicitor to the Soviet authorities details a pension that Mary Lee Ware set for Rudolf and which continued to Frieda until 1941 - after which Mrs. Blaschka had no income at all.<ref name=harvard />
It is known that, upon death, Mary's will detailed the donation of her taxidermied bird and animal collection to the [[Ingalls Memorial Library]] of Rindge — "The collection native to this region was donated through the generosity and under the will of Mary Lee Ware. It is quite a wonderful collection and many Rindge residents know of its existence because of school visits."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://208.112.52.16/Library_Services.cfm|title=Welcome to the Town of Rindge - Ingalls Memorial Library Miscellaneous Services|website=208.112.52.16|access-date=2018-04-24}}</ref> She also left them $5000 and, furthermore, was one of the Trustees of and partly responsible for writing the Annual Report of the Library, as she was a signatory of said Report in 1917; this also made her one of the Officers of the Town of Rindge.<ref>Rindge. "Annual Reports of the Officers of the Town of Rindge, N. H.: For the Year Ending March 1 and the Invoice and Taxes for April 1." Print. - page 22</ref> At some point in life Mary Lee Ware inherited [[Robert Salmon]]'s ''[[The British Fleet Forming a Line off Algiers]]'' painting from her father, Dr. Charles Eliot Ware - though how he acquired it is not known. She bequeathed the painting in 1937 (presumably after her death and per her will) to the [[Museum of Fine Arts, Boston|Museum of Fine Arts (MFA)]] in Boston, Massachusetts.<ref name="mfa.org"/><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.davidrumsey.com/amica/amico887359-17785.html|title=Robert Salmon / The British Fleet Forming a Line off Algiers / 1829|website=www.davidrumsey.com|access-date=2018-04-24}}</ref> Additionally, Miss Ware's will detailed sizable donations to organizations such as the [[Massachusetts General Hospital]], Kentucky's [[Berea College]], and the [[American Unitarian Association]].<ref name=harvard /><ref name="hoofandclaw.org"/> In addition,<ref name=harvard />
==Miscellaneous== The independent wealth of Mary L. Ware and her family was owed to the fact that her mother, Elizabeth C. Ware, was a descendant of the wealthy [[Salem, Massachusetts|Salem]] [[Cabot family|Cabots]] - a merchant family dating back to the early 1700s.<ref>The Cabot Family - http://library.albany.edu/preservation/brittle_bks/Crawford_Familiesv1/Chpt9.pdf</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ancestry.com/genealogy/records/elizabeth-cabot-lee_28529786|title=Elizabeth Cabot Lee 1819-1898 - Ancestry|website=www.ancestry.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-04-24}}</ref>
In 1900 Miss Ware began a subscription to the [[Fund for the Encouragement of Mexican and Central American Research]], as recorded in a Harvard University Annual Report.<ref>{{cite book|title=Annual reports of the President and Treasurer of Harvard College|date=1900–1901|publisher=Harvard University|page=5325|url=http://pds.lib.harvard.edu/pds/view/2574409?n=5325|accessdate=14 January 2016}}</ref>
The rug on the floor of the Edward Hall Library in the [[First Parish in Cambridge]] was "given in memory of Miss Mary Lee Ware, a first cousin of Rev. Edward Hall," who presided as Minister from 1882 to 1893.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.harvardsquarelibrary.org/congregational-polity/for-an-industrial-society/|title=The Church in Harvard Square: For an Industrial Society|date=2014-09-09|work=Harvard Square Library|access-date=2018-04-24|language=en-US}}</ref>
Mary Lee Ware reportedly never owned an automobile - apparently traveling to and from Boston via the train, and by horse and buggy when in Rindge.<ref name="hoofandclaw.org"/>
Mary's relationship with her brother, Charles Ware Jr., is not known. It is known, though, that Charles Jr. also went to Harvard in the 1870s and lived in Boston for a while – marrying in 1881 – before moving to Newton. Why Mary and her mother never involved him (and his wife) in the Glass Flowers enterprise is unknown.

(Mary L. Ware)] * [http://news.harvard.edu/gazette/story/2016/05/putting-the-glass-flowers-in-new-light/ Putting the Glass Flowers in new light (Harvard Gazette)] * [http://www.cmog.org/article/glass-flowers The Glass Flowers (Corning)] * [http://news.psu.edu/story/140881/1999/09/01/research/flowers-out-glass Flowers Out of Glass (Penn State)] * [http://208.112.52.16/index.cfm Welcome to the Town of Rindge] * [http://www.nasonline.org/publications/biographical-memoirs/memoir-pdfs/goodale-george.pdf National Academy of Sciences Biographical Memoir] * [https://www.masshist.org/blog/1469 Francis Parkman's Spurs (MHS)] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20160311164611/http://www.hoofandclaw.org/ware/ Hoof&Claw - Ware Farm ] * [http://www.warefamilies.org/ Ware - A Place Ware We Can Meet] * [http://library.albany.edu/preservation/brittle_bks/Crawford_Familiesv1/Chpt9.pdf The Cabot Family]

revision.text:
'''Nicolas Véron''' is a French economist. He is a Senior Fellow at [[Bruegel (institution)|Bruegel]] in [[Brussels]], which he co-founded in 2002-05, and at the [[Peterson Institute for International Economics]] in [[Washington DC]], which he joined in 2009. In 2012, he was included in the global [[50 Most Influential (Bloomberg Markets ranking)|50 Most Influential]] list of [[Bloomberg Markets]] Magazine.<ref>{{cite web|website=Bloomberg Business|author=Bloomberg Markets|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/slideshow/39/2012-09-04/bloomberg-markets-50-most-influential.html|date=September 5, 2012|title=Bloomberg Markets' 50 Most Influential}}</ref>
==Research and career==
Véron is an alumnus of [[École Polytechnique]] and of [[École nationale supérieure des mines de Paris]] where he received the [[Corps des mines]] training. He was a French civil servant from 1995 to 2000, first in the [[Prefectures in France|Prefecture]] in [[Lille]] then as the corporate advisor to Labor Minister [[Martine Aubry]] in the [[Lionel Jospin|Jospin]] government. In 2000-02 he worked for publicly listed French Internet company MultiMania, later renamed [[Lycos]] France, as VP Business Development then [[Chief Financial Officer]]. He then cofounded [[Bruegel (institution)|Bruegel]] together with [[Jean Pisani-Ferry]], starting in 2002.<ref>{{cite web|website=Bruegel|title=Annual Report 2015|url=http://bruegel.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/04/Bruegel_AR_2015_Web.pdf}}</ref>
His research focuses on banking and financial regulation, including in recent years European [[Banking union]]. He has testified before the [[US Senate]],<ref>{{cite web|website=U.S. Senate Committee on Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs|url=http://banking.senate.gov/public/index.cfm?FuseAction=Hearings.Hearing&Hearing_ID=a946a668-dbb6-47e3-b8b4-07da5c413819|title=The European Debt and Financial Crisis: Origins, Options, and Implications of the US and Global Economy|date=September 22, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|website=U.S. Senate Committee on Foreign Relations|title=The Future of the Eurozone: Outlook and Lessons|date=August 1, 2012|url=http://www.foreign.senate.gov/hearings/the-future-of-the-eurozone-outlook-and-lessons}}</ref> the [[European Parliament]], the UK [[House of Lords]], the [[Assembly of the Republic (Portugal)|Portuguese National Assembly]], the Italian Parliament and the German [[Bundestag]].<ref>{{cite web|website= Deutscher Bundestag, Finanzausschuss|url=http://www.bundestag.de/ausschuesse18/a07/anhoerungen/117--sitz-/508222|title=Öffentliche Anhörung zu dem Thema "Europäisches System der Finanzaufsicht"|date=May 31, 2017}}</ref>
Véron became an independent board member of the derivatives arm (Global [[Trade Repository]]) of [[Depository Trust & Clearing Corporation|DTCC]] in July 2013. From 2014 to 2016 he was also a member of the Scientific Advisory Board of [[Autorité des marchés financiers (France)|AMF]], France's securities regulator.<ref>{{cite web|website=Autorité des marchés financiers|title=About the AMF's Scientific Advisory Board|date=January 3, 2014|url=http://www.amf-france.org/en_US/L-AMF/Conseil-scientifique.html?langSwitch=true}}</ref>
== Selected publications == * [https://www.amazon.fr/Larchitecture-villes-Ricardo-Bofill/dp/2738103049 ''L'Architecture des villes''], with [[Ricardo Bofill]] ([[Odile Jacob]] Publisher, 1995 – {{ISBN|2-7381-0304-9}}) * [http://www.cornellpress.cornell.edu/book/?GCOI=80140100735930 ''Smoke & Mirrors, Inc.: Accounting for Capitalism''], with Matthieu Autret and Alfred Galichon ([[Cornell University Press]], 2006 – {{ISBN|978-0-8014-4416-6}}) * [http://www.bruegel.org/publications/publication-detail/publication/13-the-global-accounting-experiment/ ''The Global Accounting Experiment''] ([[Bruegel (institution)|Bruegel]], 2007 – {{ISBN|978-90-78910-02-2}}) * [http://www.lignes-de-reperes.com/catalogue/dereglement-capitalisme3.htm ''Le grand dérèglement – Chroniques du capitalisme financier''] (Lignes de Repères, 2009 – {{ISBN|978-2-915752-46-5}}) * [https://www.amazon.com/Transatlantic-Challenges-Multipolarity-Institute-International/dp/0881326453 ''Transatlantic Economic Challenges in an Era of Growing Multipolarity''], co-editor with Jacob Funk Kirkegaard and [[Guntram Wolff]] ([[Peterson Institute for International Economics]], 2012 – {{ISBN|978-0-88132-645-1}}) * [http://entempsreel.com/nouveau-cahier-de-nicolas-veron-lunion-bancaire-un-succes-europeen/ ''L'Union bancaire, un succès européen''] (En Temps Réel, 2014 – {{ISBN|978-2-915897-85-2}}) * [http://www.bruegel.org/publications/publication-detail/publication/880-europes-radical-banking-union/ ''Europe's Radical Banking Union''] ([[Bruegel (institution)|Bruegel]], 2015 - {{ISBN|978-90-78910-37-4}}) * [http://bruegel.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/Blueprint-XXV-web.pdf ''European Banking Supervision: The First Eighteen Months''], co-edited with Dirk Schoenmaker ([[Bruegel (institution)|Bruegel]], 2016 - {{ISBN|978-90-78910-41-1}})
==References== {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.nicolasveron.info/ Personal blog] * [http://www.bruegel.org/ Bruegel website] * [http://www.piie.com/ Peterson Institute website] * {{C-SPAN|nicolasveron}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Veron, Nicolas}} [[Category:French economists]] [[Category:Financial regulation]] [[Category:1971 births]] [[Category:Living people]]

{{infobox writer <!-- for more information see [[:Template:Infobox writer/doc]] --> | name = Ohad Elhelo | birth_date = December 18, 1989 | birth_place = [[Ashdod, Israel]] | occupation = [[Social Entrepreneur]] | language = Hebrew, English | nationality = Israeli | alma_mater = [[Brandeis University]], [[Brandeis International Business School]] }}
'''Ohad Elhelo''' ([[Hebrew]]: אוהד אלחלו) is an [[Israelis|Israeli]] social entrepreneur and public speaker. In 2014, Elhelo founded [[Our Generation Speaks]] and has since served as Executive Director.
== Education and career == Following the completion of his service in the [[Israel Defense Forces]] as an intelligence officer, Elhelo moved to [[Boston]] to begin his studies at [[Brandeis University]] as a Sylvia and Joseph Slifka Israeli Coexistence Scholar.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.abrahamfund.org/2890|title=Slifka and Malkin Coexistence Scholarship Programs 2010|website=www.abrahamfund.org|language=he|access-date=2017-05-09}}</ref> In 2016, he received his Bachelor’s degree in Economics and continued his studies at the [[Brandeis International Business School]], working towards a Master’s degree in International Economics and Finance. He received his Master’s degree in May 2017.
While a junior in college, Elhelo founded Our Generation Speaks (OGS). OGS is a fellowship program and startup incubator whose mіѕѕіоn іѕ to bring together young [[Israelis|Israeli]] and [[Palestinian people|Palestinian]] leaders through entrepreneurship.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ogspeaks.com/about-ogs|title=Our Generation Speaks|last=|first=|date=|website=Our Generation Speaks|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-05-07}}</ref> In 2016, he initiated partnerships between OGS and the [[Heller School for Social Policy and Management]] <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://heller.brandeis.edu/about/ourgenerationspeaks/|title=Our Generation Speaks {{!}} The Heller School at Brandeis University|website=heller.brandeis.edu|language=en|access-date=2017-05-09}}</ref> and [[MassChallenge]] <ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.betaboston.com/news/2016/03/10/can-enterpeneurship-bridge-the-israeli-palestinian-gap/|title=Can entrepreneurship bridge the Israeli-Palestinian gap?|last=Kirsner|first=Scott|date=|work=The Boston Globe|access-date=2017-04-28|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-US}}</ref> to launch the fellowship program. To date, the venture has raised nearly $4 million.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/richardbehar/2017/03/21/backed-by-big-wheels-a-boston-incubator-hooks-up-young-israelis-and-palestinians-to-launch-startups/#3127c4426424|title=Backed By Big Wheels, A Boston Incubator Hooks Up Young Israelis And Palestinians To Launch Startups|last=Behar|first=Richard|date=March 21, 2017|website=www.forbes.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-05-09}}</ref>
For his work pertaining to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, he has been featured as a speaker at universities, synagogues, and in public forums across the United States.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/his-generation-speaks-qa-with-social-entrepreneur_us_585883a0e4b0d5f48e165242|title=Their Generation Speaks: Q&A With Social Entrepreneur, Ohad Elhelo|last=Rabin|first=Yuval|date=2016-12-20|website=Huffington Post|language=en-US|access-date=2017-05-09}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.themarker.com/allnews/1.4057601#article-comments|title=לקחנו הימור": אוהד אלחלו חזר מיואש מהמלחמה - זה מה שהוא החליט לעשות|last=Rubin|first=Eliran|date=May 1, 2017|work=TheMarker|access-date=2017-05-09|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=he}}</ref>
==References== <references />
{{authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Elhelo, Ohad}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Israeli businesspeople]] [[Category:Social entrepreneurs]] [[Category:Brandeis University alumni]] [[Category:1989 births]]

revision.text:
{{infobox person | name = Richard Mortimer | image = | birth_date = {{birth date|1852|04|24}} | birth_place = [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]], U.S. | death_date = {{death date and age|1918|03|16|1852|04|24}} | death_place = [[Palm Beach, Florida]], U.S. | education = | alma_mater = | party = | parents = William Yates Mortimer
Anna Elizabeth Thorpe Mortimer | spouse = {{marriage|[[Eleanor Jay Chapman Mortimer|Eleanor Jay Chapman]]
|April 26, 1886|1918|reason=his death}} | children = 4 | relations = [[Katharine Mortimer]] (granddaughter)
[[John Jay Mortimer]] (grandson) }} '''Richard Mortimer''' (April 24, 1852 – March 15, 1918) was an American real estate investor and society leader during the [[Gilded Age]]. ==Early life== Mortimer was born in New York City on April 24, 1852. He was the son of William Yates Mortimer (1824–1891) of New York and Anna Elizabeth ([[née]] Thorpe) Mortimer (1829–1905) of Albany. His siblings included Minnie Mortimer and Wilfred Mortimer, both of whom died young.{{cite news |title=WILLIAM YATES MORTIMER |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1891/12/05/103354529.pdf |accessdate=18 October 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=December 5, 1891}} His younger brother, Stanley Yates Mortimer,{{cite news |title=STANLEY MORTIMER DEAD AT AGE OF 79; Former Polo Player, Huntsman and Artist Belonged to an Old New York Family. STUDIED PAINTING IN PARIS He Was a Founder of the Meadow Brook Club and Was Noted as a Skillful and Fearless Rider. |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1932/03/25/100702261.pdf |accessdate=18 October 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=March 25, 1932 |language=en}} was married to [[Elizabeth Livingston Hall Mortimer|Elizabeth Livingston Hall]],{{refn|group=lower-alpha|Elizabeth's sister, [[Anna Hall Roosevelt|Anna Rebecca Hall]] (mother of [[First Lady of the United States|First Lady]], [[Eleanor Roosevelt]]), was married to [[Elliott Bulloch Roosevelt]], the son of [[Theodore Roosevelt Sr.]] and brother of U.S. President [[Theodore Roosevelt]].{{cite book |last1=Reynolds |first1=Cuyler |title=Genealogical and Family History of Southern New York and the Hudson River Valley: A Record of the Achievements of Her People in the Making of a Commonwealth and the Building of a Nation |date=1914 |publisher=Lewis Historical Publishing Company |page=1332 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iNIUAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA1332&lpg=PA1332 |accessdate=14 June 2018 |language=en}}}} the second daughter of socialite, banker, and merchant, [[Valentine Hall Jr.]]{{cite web |title=Mrs. Stanley Mortimer (1863-1944) |url=https://www.nyhistory.org/exhibit/mrs-stanley-mortimer-1863-1944 |website=www.nyhistory.org |publisher=[[New-York Historical Society]] |accessdate=14 June 2018 |language=en}}{{refn|group=lower-alpha|Stanley and Elizabeth's daughter, Edith Mortimer, was married to Italian Count Mario di Zoppola in 1919.{{cite news |title=MISS E. MORTIMER WEDS ITALIAN COUNT {{!}} The Bride of Mario di Zoppola, Aviator, at Parents' Country Home, Wheatley Hills. |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1919/06/29/98286804.pdf |accessdate=18 October 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=June 29, 1919}}}} His paternal grandparents, of which his father was the only son, were Harriette Cordelia (née Thompson) Mortimer and Richard Mortimer,{{cite book |last1=Hall |first1=Henry |title=America's Successful Men of Affairs: The City of New York |date=1895 |publisher=[[New York Tribune]] |page=456 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=X5wMAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA456&lpg=PA456 |accessdate=18 October 2018 |language=en}} a [[Cleckheaton]], [[Yorkshire]], [[England]] born merchant who came to America in 1816 and became incredibly wealthy.{{cite news |title=RICHARD MORTIMER |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1882/05/31/102778665.pdf |accessdate=18 October 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=May 31, 1882}} His grandfather was the brother-in-law of William Yates, a large woolen manufacturer. Upon his paternal grandfathers death in 1882, he inherited a large fortune.{{cite news |title=RICHARD MORTIMER'S MILLIONS. |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1882/06/06/96862637.pdf |accessdate=18 October 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=June 6, 1882}} His maternal grandfather was Aaron Thorpe of [[Albany, New York]]. ==Career== [[File:(King1893NYC) pg848 MORTIMER BUILDING. WALL STREET, SOUTH SIDE, CORNER OF NEW STREET.jpg|thumb|The [[Mortimer Building]], built by Mortimer's father in 1885.]] After receiving an education in Germany, he returned to New York at the age of 20 to take over management of his families estate, which was founded by his grandfather (including the first [[935-939 Broadway|Mortimer Building]] on Broadway and held the early offices of the [[American Institute of Architects]]) and greatly expanded by his father, including the construction of the [[Mortimer Building]] which was completed in 1885.{{cite news |title=MORTIMER FAMILY REALTY. How Wise Investments a Century Ago Made Decedents Wealthy. |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1918/11/24/97046477.pdf |accessdate=18 October 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=November 24, 1918}} Shortly after his death, the [[New York Stock Exchange]] acquired the Mortimer Building for $745,000 in December 1918.{{cite news |title=Exchange Buys Mortimer Building. |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1918/12/12/97050475.pdf |accessdate=18 October 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=December 12, 1918}} The Mortimer families real estate holdings were quite extensive, but smaller than the [[Astor family|Astors]], [[Goelet family|Goelets]], and only a few other families. ===Society life=== [[File:Mortemar, Tuxedo Park, 1905.jpg|thumb|Mortemar, the Mortimers home in [[Tuxedo Park, New York|Tuxedo Park]], c. 1905.]] In 1892, Mortimer and his wife Eleanor were included in [[Ward McAllister]]'s [[Ward McAllister#"The Four Hundred"|"Four Hundred"]], purported to be an index of New York's best families, published in ''[[The New York Times]]''.{{cite news|last1=McAllister|first1=Ward|title=THE ONLY FOUR HUNDRED {{!}} WARD M'ALLISTER GIVES OUT THE OFFICIAL LIST. HERE ARE THE NAMES, DON'T YOU KNOW, ON THE AUTHORITY OF THEIR GREAT LEADER, YOU UNDER- STAND, AND THEREFORE GENUINE, YOU SEE.|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1892/02/16/108210917.pdf|accessdate=26 March 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=16 February 1892|language=en}}{{cite book|last1=Patterson|first1=Jerry E.|title=The First Four Hundred: Mrs. Astor's New York in the Gilded Age|date=2000|publisher=[[Random House]]|isbn=9780847822089|page=218|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZLwMAAAAYAAJ|accessdate=2 March 2018|language=en}} Conveniently, 400 was the number of people that could fit into [[Mrs. Astor]]'s ballroom.{{cite book|last1=Keister|first1=Lisa A.|title=Getting Rich: America's New Rich and How They Got That Way|date=2005|publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]]|isbn=9780521536677|page=36|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5dAtJf1hmAUC&pg=PA36|accessdate=20 October 2017|language=en}}{{cite book|last1=Birmingham|first1=Stephen|title=Life at the Dakota: New York's Most Unusual Address|date=2015|publisher=Open Road Media|isbn=9781504026314|page=18|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MtPSCgAAQBAJ&pg=PT18|accessdate=2 March 2018|language=en}} Mortimer, a member of the [[Tuxedo Club]], [[The Metropolitan Club|Metropolitan Club]], [[Knickerbocker Club]], [[Union Club of the City of New York|Union Club]], [[City Club of New York|City Club]], [[Racquet and Tennis Club|Racquet Club]], Coaching Club, Riding Club and [[Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show|Westminster Kennel Club]], wore a cravat that covered his throat with "a diamond stickpin so big that his friends called him "Flashlight Dick."{{cite book |last1=Pell |first1=Eve |title=We Used to Own the Bronx: Memoirs of a Former Debutante |date=2009 |publisher=[[SUNY Press]] |isbn=9781438425146 |pages=17-18 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZFmdQQ6B1ZsC&pg=PA17 |accessdate=18 October 2018 |language=en}} The Mortimers, along with the [[Lorillard Tobacco Company|Lorillard]]s, are considered among the founding families of [[Tuxedo Park, New York]].{{cite book|last1=Conant|first1=Jennet|title=Tuxedo Park: A Wall Street Tycoon and the Secret Palace of Science That Changed the Course of World War II|date=2013|publisher=[[Simon and Schuster]]|isbn=9781476767291|page=59|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QQTZAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA59&lpg=PA59|accessdate=12 October 2017|language=en}}{{cite book |title=Social Register, New York |date=1920 |publisher=[[Social Register Association]] |page=498 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ek5IAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA498 |accessdate=18 October 2018 |language=en}} Their home in Tuxedo was known as Mortemar, a "turreted four-story mansion." Construction on Mortemar, which was designed by [[Richard Howland Hunt]] of [[Hunt & Hunt]], began in the 1890s and continued for 10 years, getting larger and larger.{{cite news |last1=L. |first1=Zach |title='Mortemar' |url=http://www.beyondthegildedage.com/2012/05/mortemar.html |accessdate=18 October 2018 |work=www.beyondthegildedage.com |date=May 12, 2012}} ==Personal life== On April 26, 1886, Mortimer was married to [[Eleanor Jay Chapman Mortimer|Eleanor Jay Chapman]] (1864–1929), a direct descendant of [[John Jay]], the first [[Chief Justice of the United States]].{{cite news |title=MRS. RICHARD MORTIMER.; Former Eleanor Jay Chapman Dies After a Long Illness. |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1929/12/10/94219894.pdf |accessdate=18 October 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=December 10, 1929 |language=en}} Eleanor was the sister of [[John Jay Chapman]] (husband to [[Elizabeth Astor Winthrop Chanler]]),{{cite book |last1=Howe |first1=Mark Antony De Wolfe |title=John Jay Chapman and His Letters ... |date=1937 |publisher=[[Houghton Mifflin]] |pages=334, 485 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=U0UOAAAAMAAJ |accessdate=18 October 2018 |language=en}}{{cite news|title=JOHN J. CHAPMAN, AUTHOR, POET, DIES; New Yorker Succumbs to Long Illness at Age of 71 in Poughkeepsie Hospital {{!}} ABANDONED LAW TO WRITE {{!}} Was Central Figure in Several Controversies Funeral in This City Next Wednesday.|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9A0DE7DB1731E333A25756C0A9679D946294D6CF&legacy=true|accessdate=12 October 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=5 November 1933}} and the daughter of Eleanor (née Jay) Chapman (daughter of [[John Jay (lawyer)|John Jay]], the [[United States Ambassador to Austria|U.S. Minister to Austria-Hungary]] under [[Ulysses S. Grant|Grant]]) and Henry Grafton Chapman Jr. (son of [[Abolitionism in the United States|abolitionist]] [[Maria Weston Chapman]]), the president of the [[New York Stock Exchange]].{{cite news|title=Obituary -- Henry G. Chapman|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9B0CE3DA1631E433A25754C1A9659C94629FD7CF&legacy=true|accessdate=12 October 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=17 March 1883}} Together, they had a townhouse at 382 Fifth Avenue and were the parents of: * Mary Eleanor Mortimer (1887–1958), who married Maxime Hubert Furlaud (1877–1973). * Richard Mortimer Jr. (1888–1918),{{cite news |title=RICHARD MORTIMER KILLED. Family at Tuxedo Gets News of Aviator's Death in France. |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1918/05/28/118141671.pdf |accessdate=18 October 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=May 28, 1918}} a Harvard graduate who died in a plane crash in France.{{cite book |last1=Howe |first1=Mark Antony De Wolfe |title=Memoirs of the Harvard Dead in the War Against Germany |date=1922 |publisher=[[Harvard University Press]] |pages=76-81 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nG4vAQAAIAAJ&pg=PA76&lpg=PA76 |accessdate=18 October 2018 |language=en}} * Stanley Grafton Mortimer (1889–1947),{{cite news|last1=Staff|title=S.G. MORTIMER DIES|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1947/04/06/96582843.html?pageNumber=60|accessdate=12 October 2017|website=The New York Times|date=April 6, 1947}} a stockbroker who married Katherine Hunt Tilford (1890–1970) in 1911.{{cite news |title=Miss Katharine Tilford to Wed |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1910/09/27/105093115.pdf |accessdate=18 October 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=September 27, 1910}}{{cite news|title=Deaths BLAINE, KATHARINE MORTIMER|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/04/17/classified/paid-notice-deaths-blaine-katharine-morti-mer.html|accessdate=12 October 2017|website=The New York Times|date=April 17, 2003}} * Wilfreda Mortimer (1892–1968), who married John Morris Livingston Rutherfurd (1888–1971), a descendant of [[U.S. Senator]] [[John Rutherfurd]] and signer of the Declaration of Independence [[Lewis Morris]], in 1911.{{cite news |title=Rutherford-Mortimer Wedding In June |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1911/01/19/106724770.pdf |accessdate=18 October 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=January 19, 1911}}{{cite news |title=MISS MORTIMER A TUXEDO BRIDE {{!}} Daughter of Richard Mortimer Married to John M. Rutherford at "Mortemar" |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1911/05/21/104825610.pdf |accessdate=18 October 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=May 21, 1911}} They divorced in Paris in 1923 and she married Charles Frederick Frothingham Jr. (1888–1963) in November 1924.{{cite news |title=MRS. RUTHERFURD GETS LICENSE TO MARRY {{!}} Former Wife of John M. L. Rutherfurd to Wed Charles F. Frothingham on Nov. 5. |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1924/10/31/101619332.pdf |accessdate=18 October 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=October 31, 1924 |language=en}}{{cite news |title=MRS. RUTHERFURD WED IN CITY CHAPEL; Former Wife of John M. L. Rutherfurd Marries Charles F. Frothingham, Broker. CITY CLERK OFFICIATES Relatives of Union Club Member and His Bride Witness the Ceremony--Other Nuptials. |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1924/11/06/104056756.pdf |accessdate=18 October 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=November 6, 1924 |language=en}} Mortimer died on March 15, 1918 in [[Palm Beach, Florida]], where he had gone for his health.{{cite news |title=RICHARD MORTIMER |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1918/03/16/98260980.pdf |accessdate=18 October 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=March 16, 1918}} He was buried at St. Mary's Church Cemetery in [[Tuxedo Park, New York]]. His entire estate was left to his widow, Eleanor,{{cite news |title=Richard Mortimer's Will Filed. |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1918/05/01/102698224.pdf |accessdate=18 October 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=May 1, 1918}} who died at her home, 555 [[Park Avenue]], after several months illness, in December 1929. ===Descendants=== Through his daughter Mary, he was the grandfather of Richard Mortimer Furlaud (1923–2018),{{cite news |last1=Hagerty |first1=James R. |title=Squibb CEO Furlaud Was Spurred by a Depression-Era Drop in Status |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/squibb-ceo-furlaud-was-spurred-by-a-depression-era-drop-in-status-1537540202 |accessdate=18 October 2018 |work=[[Wall Street Journal]] |date=21 September 2018}} the president and C.E.O. of [[Beech-Nut|Squibb Beech-Nut]] (which became [[Bristol-Myers Squibb]]);{{cite news |title=Richard M. Furlaud, 95 |url=https://easthamptonstar.com/Obituaries/2018913/Richard-M-Furlaud-95 |accessdate=18 October 2018 |work=[[The East Hampton Star]] |date=September 13, 2018 |language=en}} and Maxime Jay Furlaud (1925–1999). Through his son Stanley, he was the grandfather of Stanley G. Mortimer, Jr. (1913–1999),{{cite news|title=Paid Notice: Deaths MORTIMER, STANLEY G.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/08/13/classified/paid-notice-deaths-mortimer-stanley-g.html|accessdate=12 October 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=13 August 1999}} who was married to [[Babe Paley]],{{cite news |author= |coauthors= |title=Barbara Cushing Paley Dies at 63; Style Pace-Setter in Three Decades; Symbol of Taste |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1978/07/07/archives/barbara-cushing-paley-dies-at-63-style-pacesetter-in-three-decades.html |quote=Barbara Cushing Paley, the wife of William S. Paley, the chairman of the board of the Columbia Broadcasting System, died of cancer at their apartment in New York City yesterday after a long illness. She was 63 years old. |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=July 7, 1978 |accessdate=12 October 2017| first=Enid | last=Nemy}} and then [[W. Averell Harriman|Kathleen Harriman]];{{cite news|last1=Nemy|first1=Enid|title=Stanley G. Mortimer Jr., 86, Sportsman and Ad Executive|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/08/14/nyregion/stanley-g-mortimer-jr-86-sportsman-and-ad-executive.html|accessdate=12 October 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=14 August 1999}}{{cite news|last1=Fox|first1=Margalit|title=Kathleen Mortimer, Rich and Adventurous, Dies at 93|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/20/us/20mortimer.html|accessdate=12 October 2017|website=The New York Times|date=February 19, 2011}} Henry Tilford Mortimer (1916–1993),{{cite news|last1=Staff|title=Henry T. Mortimer; Stockbroker, 77|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1993/09/08/obituaries/henry-t-mortimer-stockbroker-77.html|accessdate=12 October 2017|website=The New York Times|date=September 8, 1993}} Richard Mortimer, Eve Mortimer (1918–2007),{{cite news|title=Eve Mortimer Ledyard of West Grove|url=http://www.dailylocal.com/article/DL/20071004/TMP01/310049987|accessdate=12 October 2017|date=10 October 2007|language=en}} who married Clarence Pell, Jr.,{{cite news|last1=Morgan|first1=Spencer|title=The Mortimer Family|url=https://observer.com/2006/12/the-mortimer-family/|accessdate=12 October 2017|work=[[Observer Media|Observer]]|date=18 December 2006}} and later [[Lewis Cass Ledyard]] III;{{cite news|last1=Wallace|first1=Andrew|title=Lewis C. Ledyard 3d, A Lawyer Who Turned To Art, Horse Breeding|url=http://articles.philly.com/1990-12-05/news/25921847_1_yearlings-farm-lawyer|accessdate=12 October 2017|website=The Philadelphia Inquirer|date=December 5, 1990}} [[Katharine Mortimer]] (1923–2003), who married three times (including to [[Francis Xavier Shields]] and becoming grandmother of actress [[Brooke Shields]]);{{cite news|title=Deaths BLAINE, KATHARINE MORTIMER|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/04/17/classified/paid-notice-deaths-blaine-katharine-morti-mer.html|accessdate=15 March 2016|website=The New York Times|date=12 October 2017}} and [[John Jay Mortimer]] (1935–2013), a prominent financier.{{cite news|last1=Theodoracopulos|first1=Taki|title=Taki: RIP John Jay, my brave friend who refused to take part in vulture capitalism|url=https://www.spectator.co.uk/2013/11/john-jay-mortimer-was-the-epitome-of-a-gent/|accessdate=12 October 2017|work=[[The Spectator]]|date=9 November 2013}} Through his daughter Wilfreda, he was the grandfather of John Mortimer Rutherford (1913–1966); Jay Rutherford (1916–2005); and Nathaniel Frothingham (1927–2001). ==References== ;Notes {{Reflist|group=lower-alpha}} ;Sources {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== *{{fg|191701824}} * ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=JLRCAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA461 Architectural Record, Volume 18]'', featuring "Mortemar" (1905) {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Mortimer, Richard}} [[Category:1852 births]] [[Category:1918 deaths]] [[Category:Mortimer family of New York]] [[Category:People included in New York Society's Four Hundred]]

revision.text:
{{about|the Spanish term}} [[Image:Roto chileno.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Monument to the Chilean '''''roto''''', [[Plaza Yungay]], Santiago.]] [[Image:BoliviaChile.jpg|thumb|350px|right|Example of recent expressions of Bolivian irredentism over territorial losses in the [[War of the Pacific]] (1879–1884). In the mural it is written; "What once was ours, will be ours once again", and "Hold on rotos (Chileans), because here come the Colorados of Bolivia"]] '''''Roto''''', f. '''''rota''''', (literally "broken") is a term used to refer to Chilean people and in particular to the common Chilean. In [[Chile]] from the start of the 20th century it was applied with a negative [[classism|classist]] connotation to poor city-dwellers. It is also used contemptuously in other Spanish-speaking countries, especially [[Bolivia]]<!---BROKEN LINK---><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.batallas.org/viewtopic.php?p=158950&sid=c490b82637a239cfcdcd6a52ee9f9b64|title=Los Colorados de Bolivia en la Guerra del Pacífico|accessdate=|format=PHP|author=|date=|publisher=www.batallas.org}}{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> and [[Peru]], to refer to Chileans in a derogatory manner. Otherwise, despite its defects, the roto is also considered a figure of national identity and pride in Chile.
==Historical usage== The term ''roto'' has been used in [[Peru]] since the times of the [[Spanish conquest of the Inca Empire|Spanish conquest]], when [[Diego de Almagro]]'s disappointed troops returned to [[Cusco|Cuzco]] (after a failed gold-seeking expedition in Chile) with their torn clothes, due to the extensive and laborious passage on foot through the [[Atacama desert]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://diario.elmercurio.com/detalle/index.asp?id={ff7d780d-671b-41f1-8ab2-a07c851aaa16} |title=Roto chileno |accessdate=2 August 2013 |format=ASP |author=Cañas Palacios, Gastón |date=20 September 2010 |publisher=diario.elmercurio.com |quote= |language=Spanish}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |author=Larraín Valdés, Gerardo |title=Diego de Almagro |url= |format= |year=2001 |origyear=1996 |editor= |publisher=Luxemburgo |isbn=956-272-488-3 |language=Spanish |quote=[...] los [españoles que volvieron] de Chile estaban en tan pobres condiciones, ya que nadie les daba trabajo ni posibilidades de desenvolverse en alguna actividad, que por sus ropas harapientas los llamaban los '''rotos''' chilenos.}}</ref>
This term became more used after the [[War of the Confederation|Chilean campaigns against the Peru-Bolivian Confederation]] in 1839 —Chilean troops defeated the confederation at the [[Battle of Yungay]] on 20 January 1839.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.academiahistoriamilitar.cl/?do=noticias.verDetalle&id=86 |title=Batalla de Yungay y conmemoración del roto chileno – Yungay y el roto chileno: El proceso de consolidación de la nacionalidad |accessdate=15 October 2012 |author=López Ardiles, Marcos |date=17 January 2012 |publisher=www.academiahistoriamilitar.cl |language=Spanish}}</ref> In Chile tributes were paid to the victors of Yungay and, in a gesture of recognition, 20 January was declared the [[:es:Día del Roto Chileno|''Día del Roto Chileno'']] (in Spanish; ''Day of the Chilean Roto'')<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.feriadoschilenos.cl/DiasNacionales.html#DiaDelRotoChileno |title=Días nacionales en Chile: Otros días en que se observan celebraciones |accessdate=17 March 2013 |author=Farah, Miguel |date=14 March 2013 |publisher=www.feriadoschilenos.cl |language=Spanish}}</ref>— and the [[War of the Pacific]] (1879–84).
The figure of the ''Chilean Roto'' is commemorated by very diverse organisations and actors such as the [[Chilean Army]], ultra-nationalist activists, the Communist Party and local organisations of ordinary citizens. The Army has a particular appreciation to the figure which was regarded as the main hero –a collective and anonymous hero- of some of the most crucial battles in the war against Bolivia and Peru. In this context, the webpage of the Chilean Army states:<ref>http://www.ejercito.cl/historia/hisp-ind.htm {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071005011805/http://www.ejercito.cl/historia/hisp-ind.htm |date=5 October 2007 }}; 15 December 2004</ref>
The patriotism, bravery and heroism was embodied in the Chilean roto, who represents the ordinary man that left all to fight for its country. This was the one who fought in Yungay and characterised himself by his fierceness and determination.<ref>[http://www.oresteplath.cl/antologia/origen-roto.html ''Epopeya del “roto” chileno''], by Oreste Plath.</ref><ref>[http://www.scielo.cl/scielo.php?script=sci_arttext&pid=S0718-23762010000100009&lng=es&nrm=iso&tlng=es ''Exaltación del mestizo: la invención del roto chileno''], by Horacio Gutiérrez.</ref>
==See also== *[[Descamisado]]
==References== <references/> {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2010}}
